summary.para: Most of the classes in the namespace are abstract and implemented by manufacturers of Gadgeteer modules. Users of modules in production should use the F1 documentation available in the .NET Gadgeteer Designer. Select a module on the visual design surface and push the F1 key.
An exception is the class that supports tasks such as displaying text, simple shapes, and images by display modules.

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module
member.summary: Abstract class to provide common methods, properties, and events for modules.
member.remarks: All module classes derive from this class, either directly or indirectly. Classes that represent a module that can be chained together with other modules on the same socket derive from , which dervies from this class.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.modules
member.summary: Stores a list of modules so that they will not be garbage collected even if user code stops referring to them. (Because some modules are interrupt-driven, they can receive events even then.)

member.summary: If is true, prints the name of this module and a specified message to the debug output window.

member.remarks: If is false, the default, calling this method has no effect.

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.DaisyLinkModule
member.summary: Abstract class to provide common methods, properties, and events for DaisyLink modules that can be chained together on the same socket.
member.remarks: The class is the base class for all DaisyLink modules that are capable of being chained together on the same socket. When you use chained modules, you instantiate each corresponding object by providing the same socket to the object constructor. For DaisyLink modules (using type X or Y), pin 3 is for the DaisyLink neighbor bus, pin 4 is used for I2C SDA, pin 5 is used for I2C SCL. See the DaisyLink specification in Appendix 1 of the Microsoft .NET Gadgeteer Module Builderâ€™s Guide for more details.

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.SoftwareI2C
member.summary: Supports software I2C on any GPIO pins using socket type X or Y.
member.remarks: The module must include pull up resistors in the range 2.2kohm to 10kohm. Hardware I2C (Type I, using Gadgeteer.Interfaces.I2CBus) modules are not cross-compatible with SoftwareI2C unless they include switchable pull-ups (and the module code switches them in if it detects Type I is not present). If the mainboard provides native code support for software I2C, this will be used, otherwise a managed code implementation of I2C will be used. Only "standard mode" is supported (100 kbit/s maximum, though the speed may be slower). For a fast interface, use hardware I2C (Gadgeteer.Interfaces.I2CBus) or another bus type.

member.name: M:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.SoftwareI2C.#ctor(Gadgeteer.Socket,Gadgeteer.Socket.Pin,Gadgeteer.Socket.Pin,Gadgeteer.Modules.Module)
member.remarks: This automatically checks that the socket supports Type X or Y as appropriate, and reserves the SDA and SCL pins. An exception will be thrown if there is a problem with these checks.
member.param: The socket for this software I2C device interface.
The socket pin used for I2C data.
The socket pin used for I2C clock.
The module using this I2C interface, which can be null if unspecified.

member.name: P:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.NetworkModule.IsNetworkUp
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the network connection is up.

remarks.para: When this property is true, the network connection is connected ( is true) and IP settings are configured (either statically or using DHCP as requested).
remarks.note: When this property is true, it does not necessarily mean that the network connection is functional. The IP configuration for the network connection may be invalid for the network that it is connected to.

member.summary: Gets a NetworkInterface object that describes the settings associated with this network module.

member.name: P:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.NetworkModule.IsNetworkConnected
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether this network is connected.
member.remarks: Derived classes override this property to return a value that indicates whether the media state is connected. This does not necessarily mean that the network connection is functional.

member.name: E:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.NetworkModule.NetworkUp
member.summary: Raised when network is connected and configured for Internet Proctocol (IP) communication tasks.

remarks.para: Handle this event to perform tasks associated with the network state. This event is raised when changes from NetworkState.Down to NetworkState.Up. If the network is up when you add an event handler, the event is raised immediately on the new handler.
remarks.note: When this event is raised, it does not necessarily mean that the network connection is functional. The IP configuration for the network connection may be invalid for the network that it is connected to.

member.name: E:Gadgeteer.Modules.Module.NetworkModule.NetworkDown
member.summary: Raised when the network connection is not able to perform network communication tasks.
member.remarks: Handle this event to perform tasks associated with the network state. This event is raised when changes from NetworkState.Up to NetworkState.Down. If the network is down when you add an event handler, the event is raised immediately on the new handler.

member.summary: The network connection is down. This might indicate an invalid configuration for the connection or disconnected media.

true if the the value received from the interrupt is greater than zero; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.InterruptInput.SynchronousUnsafeEventInvocation
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines how the event is raised.
member.remarks: An interrupt may occur on a thread other than the application thread. When is false (the default), the event, which is raised in response to the interrupt on the interface, is not raised immediately, instead it is queued for raising on the application's dispatcher thread. However, when is true, the event is raised immediately on the same thread that generated the interrupt. This results in faster interrupt processing and may be useful to respond to realtime events, but extra care must be taken when using this facility to be thread-safe, i.e. to handle issues such as locking, atomic reading/writing of streams/files, deadlock avoidance, etc.

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.SPI
member.summary: Represents a Microwire/Serial Peripheral Interface (SPI) interface to communicate with a Microwire/SPI compatible device.

remarks.para: The Microwire/SPI interface is a synchronous serial communications protocol in which multiple devices can be connected with one another by means of a single three-wire system. This three-wire system includes the serial data in the input signal, the serial data out signal, and the serial clock. You must use an additional GPIO pin as a chip select for each device that will communicate on the Microwire/SPI interface.

There are both 8-bit and 16-bit modes of operation using the overloaded read and write methods that have byte (8-bit) arguments or unsigned short (16-bit) arguments. Note that you can configure both 8-bit and 16-bit devices and have them share the SPI interface.

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Program
member.summary: Represents the main program for a Microsoft .NET Gadgeteer application.
member.remarks: The main program of your Microsoft .NET Gadgeteer application must derive from this class, and call the method, which starts the Gadgeteer dispatcher. Before a is instantiated, the static variable must be set. These tasks are normally done using a project template to provide an easy-to-follow structure for end user code.

member.name: M:Gadgeteer.Program.Run
member.summary: Starts the application, invoking the Dispatcher to handle events and timers. This call does not return.
member.exception: An attempt was made to call this method more than once.

member.name: M:Gadgeteer.Program.PulseDebugLED
member.summary: Pulses the mainboard's debug LED, if present. Note that there may be more than one LED on the mainboard. One labelled "PWR" will always be on when the mainboard is powered. The debug LED is labelled "LED" (if present). This method also writes "PulseDebugLED called" on the debug print output.
member.remarks: The Debug LED can also be turned on/off using the interface directly.

member.summary: Executes a specified delegate on the thread on which a particular object (dispatcher) was created.
member.param: A delegate to a method which is pushed into the dispatcher's event queue.
The object array to be passed as arguments to the delegate.
member.remarks: This static method is used internally by Gadgeteer interfaces and modules to raise events on your application thread. You should not call this method directly.

member.name: M:Gadgeteer.Program.CheckAndInvoke(System.Delegate,System.Delegate,System.Object[])
member.summary: Validates, and then executes a specified delegate on the dispatcher thread.
member.param: An application-specific event delegate, or null if none have been assigned.
An interface or module delegate that raises an event.
The object array to be passed as arguments to the delegate.
member.returns: true if the calling thread is the thread associated with dispatcher, otherwise false.
member.remarks: This static method is used by Gadgeteer interfaces and modules to raise events on your application thread. Apps should not need to call this method directly. See the module template for an example of the correct pattern for using this method.

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialParity
member.summary: Specifies the parity bit for a object.

remarks.para: Use this enumeration when setting the property for a serial port connection.

Parity is an error-checking procedure in which the number of 1s must always be the sameâ€”either even or oddâ€”for each group of bits that is transmitted without error. In modem-to-modem communications, parity is often one of the parameters that must be agreed upon by sending parties and receiving parties before transmission can take place.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialParity.Even
member.summary: Sets the parity bit so that the count of bits set is an even number.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialParity.Odd
member.summary: Sets the parity bit so that the count of bits set is an odd number.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialParity.Mark
member.summary: Leaves the parity bit set to 1.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialParity.Space
member.summary: Leaves the parity bit set to 0.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialParity.None
member.summary: No parity check occurs.

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialStopBits
member.summary: Specifies the number of stop bits used on the object.

remarks.para: This enumeration specifies the number of stop bits to use. Stop bits separate each unit of data on an asynchronous serial connection. They are also sent continuously when no data is available for transmission.
The None option is not supported. Setting the property to None raises an ArgumentOutOfRangeException.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialStopBits.None

member.summary: 1.5 stop bits are used.

member.name: F:Gadgeteer.Interfaces.Serial.SerialStopBits.Two

member.name: T:Gadgeteer.Socket
member.summary: A class representing a socket, which may be on a mainboard or on an expansion module such as an SPI multiplexer.
member.remarks: This class is normally not directly used by application programs, who refer to sockets by their socket number. Modules should normally use this class and the GT.Interfaces classes to access functionality required to implement their APIs. Mainboards and multiplexer modules providing sockets should use this class's SocketInterfaces subclass to declare functionalities provided on their sockets.

member.name: M:Gadgeteer.Socket.ReservePin(Gadgeteer.Socket.Pin,Gadgeteer.Modules.Module)
member.summary: Tells GadgeteerCore that a pin is being used on this socket. A will be thrown if the pin is already reserved. This is called by Gadgteeer.Interface classes automatically. Gadgeteer.Modules which do not use a Gadgeteer.Interface helper class in using a pin should call this directly. Note that Gadgeteer allows mainboard pins to be reused across multiple sockets, so the reservation check also checks if the pin is used on a different socket where the pin is shared.
member.param: The socket pin being used
The module using the socket pin (can be null, but if it is not null a more useful error message will be generated).
